text: This log is when it's alreaady shutting down . We need log earlier than that where it say something about the error. But at the same time, devnet is ahving this issue <https://fivenorthgroup.slack.com/archives/C08AP9QR7K4/p1753712113312239>

elements.text:
FAILURES IN ONBOARDING NEW VALIDATORS TO DEVNET

Splice 0.4.8 introduced an error in the Canton topology management code that adds an excess (quadratic) increase in topology state entries.

This very large increase in topology state causes the onboarding process to stall for new Validator nodes attempting to onboard to DevNet.

The Splice and Canton teams have identified the root cause and are collaborating to implement a fix.

In the meantime, we suggest that you don't attempt to onboard any new nodes to DevNet until further notice. The Splice and Canton teams will work with the Super Validators to determine how quickly a fix can be rolled out, and we'll announce here as soon as we know.

text:
Hello,
I was looking at the validator applications.
1. Pink Finance submitted an application with the dev email and so it was not approved (we require individual business addresses). You can have them re-submit an application with a better email and the process takes about a week to get through <https://sync.global/validator-request/>
2. Bitrise Capital Ltd just submitted the application, the earliest they can be approved is August 6
3.  I don't see an application for Global Blockchain Innovations, but when they apply make sure it is not with a gmail address

text: hey there, wanted to know a bit about `Extra Traffic Purchase` transactions appearing on a validator node. What is it's purpose?

elements.text: hey there, wanted to know a bit about
Extra Traffic Purchase
transactions appearing on a validator node. What is it's purpose?

text: It's your validator (generally automatically) buying traffic capacity on the synchronizer.   The validators prepay for capacity and are generally configured to automatically buy more when the available amount gets low.  The amount bought is fixed, so you can estimate your on-network data usage by the frequency of these transactions.

elements.text: It's your validator (generally automatically) buying traffic capacity on the synchronizer.   The validators prepay for capacity and are generally configured to automatically buy more when the available amount gets low.  The amount bought is fixed, so you can estimate your on-network data usage by the frequency of these transactions.

text: correct

elements.text: correct

text: I see, is there a way to determine preemptively how much traffic capacity will it need on the synchronizer? (for instance for a day).

elements.text: I see, is there a way to determine preemptively how much traffic capacity will it need on the synchronizer? (for instance for a day).

text: It's going to depend on your transaction types and volume - this thread from <#C08FQRCRFUN|gsf-global-synchronizer-appdev> <https://brale.slack.com/archives/C08FQRCRFUN/p1752598958316359> has info on how to capture the stats for your transactions
